article.paragraph: British Airways, often shortened toBA, is theflag carrierairline of theUnited Kingdomand the largest airline in theUnited Kingdombased on fleet size. When measured by passengers carried, it is second-largest inUnited Kingdom(behindeasyJet). The airline is based inWaterside (building)Watersidenear its mainAirline hubhubatLondon Heathrow Airport.

A British Airways Board was established by theUnited Kingdomgovernment in 1972 to manage the two nationalized airline corporations,British Overseas Airways CorporationandBritish European Airways, and two smaller, regional airlines,Cambrian Airways, fromCardiff, andNortheast Airlines (UK)Northeast Airlines, fromNewcastle upon Tyne. On 31 March 1974, all four companies were merged to form British Airways. After almost 13 years as a state company, British Airways was privatized in February 1987 as part of a wider privatization plan by the Conservative government. The carrier soon expanded with the acquisition ofBritish Caledonianin 1987, followed byDan-Airin 1992 andBritish Midland Internationalin 2012.

British Airways is a founding member of theOneworldairline alliance, along withAmerican Airlines,Cathay Pacific,Qantas, and the now defunctCanadian Airlines. The alliance has since grown to become the third-largest, afterSkyTeamandStar Alliance. British Airways merged withIberia (airline)Iberiaon 21 January 2011, formally creating theInternational Airlines Group(IAG), the world's third-largest airline group in terms of annual revenue and the second-largest in Europe. IAG is listed on theLondon Stock Exchangeand in theFTSE 100 Index.

A long-timeBoeingcustomer, British Airways ordered 59Airbus A320 familyaircraft in August 1998. In 2007 it purchased 12Airbus A380sand 24Boeing 787 Dreamliners, marking the start of itsflight lengthlong-haulfleet replacement. The centerpiece of the airline's long-haul fleet is theBoeing 777, with 58 in the fleet. British Airways is the largest operator of theBoeing 747-400in the world, with 53 registered to the airline.

article.paragraph: MainHistory of British AirwaysFile:British Airways Boeing 747-100 in BOAC basic livery Marmet.jpgthumbABoeing 747-100in BOAC-British Airways transition liveryIn January 1972, a British Airways Board was established by theUnited Kingdomgovernment following the passing of the Civil Aviation Act of 1971, to manageBritish Overseas Airways Corporation(BOAC) andBritish European Airways(BEA). On 1 September 1972 the management service functions of both BOAC and BEA were combined under the newly formedBritish Airways Group.

The formation ofRichard Branson'sVirgin AtlanticVirgin Atlantic Airwaysin 1984 created a competitor for BA. The intense rivalry between British Airways and Virgin Atlantic culminated in the former being sued for libel in 1993, arising from claims and counter claims over a "dirty tricks" campaign against Virgin. This campaign included allegations of poaching Virgin Atlantic customers, tampering with private files belonging to Virgin and undermining Virgin's reputation in the City. As a result of the case BA management apologised "unreservedly", and the company agreed to pay 110,000 damages to Virgin, 500,000 to Branson personally and 3 million legal costs.Cite newsBA dirty tricks against Virgin cost £3mhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/january/11/newsid_2520000/2520189.stmBBC: On This Day11 January 199323 October 2006Lord King stepped down as chairman in 1993 and was replaced by his deputy, Colin Marshall, whileRobert AylingBob Aylingtook over as CEO.Virgin filed a separate action in the US that same year regarding BA's domination of the trans-Atlantic routes, but it was thrown out in 1999.

British Airways' main base is at London Heathrow Airport, but it also has a major presence atGatwick Airport. It also has a base atLondon City Airport(LCY), where its subsidiaryBA CityFlyeris the largest operator. BA had previously operated a significant hub atManchester Airport. Manchester to New York (JFK) services were withdrawn; later all international services outside of London ceased when the subsidiaryBA Connectwas sold. Passengers wishing to travel internationally with BA either to or from regional UK destinations must now transfer in London.Cite newsFlights hit by BA sale to Flybe5 March 2007http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6418391.stmBBC News23 October 2011Heathrow Airport is dominated by British Airways, which owns 40% of the slots available at the airport.Cite newsDavidGowBA outbid for Heathrow slots21 January 2004http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2004/jan/21/theairlineindustry.britishairwaysThe GuardianUK23 October 2011The majority of BA services operate fromLondon Heathrow Terminal 5Terminal 5, with the exception of some short-haul and mid-haul flights atLondon Heathrow Terminal 1Terminal 1arising from the purchase of BMI and some short-haul flights atLondon Heathrow Terminal 3Terminal 3,cite webhttp://www.heathrowairport.com/flight-information/destinations-and-airlinesDestinations and airlines6 July 20132013owing to a lack of capacity at Terminal 5. With the imminent opening of the brand-new Terminal 2 in 2014, Star Alliance airlines will progressively be moving all their services into the new terminal and Terminal 1 will be closed for demolition in due course. British Airways' services will then be concentrated in Terminals 3 and 5.

In August 2014 Willie Walsh advised the airline would continue to use flight paths over Iraq despite the hostilities there. A few days earlier Qantas announced it would avoid Iraqi airspace, while other airlines did likewise. The issue arose following the downing ofMalaysia Airlines Flight 17over Ukraine, and a temporary suspension of flights to and fromBen Gurion Airportduring the2014 IsraelGaza conflict.cite newsBritish Airways CEO insists flights over Iraq are safehttp://www.theuknews.com/index.php/sid/224382415/scat/0f440bf3fff89f01/ht/British-Airways-CEO-insists-flights-over-Iraq-are-safe2 August 2014''The UK News''

article.heading: Industrial relations
article.paragraph: Staff working for British Airways are represented by a number of trade unions, pilots are represented byBritish Air Line Pilots' Association, cabin crew byBritish Airlines Stewards and Stewardesses Association(a branch ofUnite the Union), while other branches of Unite the Union and theGMB Unionrepresent other employees. Bob Ayling's management faced strike action by cabin crew over a 1 billion cost-cutting drive to return BA to profitability in 1997; this was the last time BA cabin crew would strike until 2009, although staff morale has reportedly been unstable since that incident.Cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2009/dec/15/british-airways-strike-backgroundThe GuardianBA strike: conflict that was always on airline's flight path15 December 20094 July 2010LondonDanMilmoIn an effort to increase interaction between management, employees, and the unions, various conferences and workshops have taken place, often with thousands in attendance.cite bookhttp://www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/?GCOIBamber, G.J., Gittell, J.H., Kochan, T.A. & von Nordenflytch, A.2009Up in the Air: How Airlines Can Improve Performance by Engaging their EmployeesCornell University Press, Ithacachapter 5

Relations have been turbulent between BA and Unite. In 2007, cabin crew threatened strike action over salary changes to be imposed by BA management. The strike was called off at the last minute, British Airways losing 80 million.In December 2009, a ballot for strike action over Christmas received a high level of support,Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8411214.stmBritish Airways cabin crew vote for Christmas strikeBBC News14 December 200924 October 2011action was blocked by a court injunction that deemed the ballot illegal. Negotiations failed to stop strike action in March, BA withdrew perks for strike participants.Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/8584720.stmBA Strikers to forfeit cheap travel perksBBC News24 March 201024 October 2011Allegations were made by theGuardiannewspaper that BA had consulted outside firms methods to undermine the unions, the story was later withdrawn.Cite newshttp://www.guardian.co.uk/theguardian/2010/apr/02/frank-burchill-apologyApology to Frank BurchillThe Guardian2 April 20106 June 2010A strike was announced for May 2010, British Airways again sought an injunction. Members of theSocialist Workers Party (Britain)Socialist Workers Partydisrupted negotiations between BA management and Unite to prevent industrial action.cite webhttp://www.socialistworker.co.uk/art.php?idRight to Work conference shows opposition to BA boss Willie WalshSocialist Worker22 May 20106 June 2010Further disruption struck whenDerek Simpson (trade unionist)Derek Simpson, a Unite co-leader, was discovered to have leaked details of confidential negotiations online via Twitter.Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/10143076.stmUnite union says BA strike to go aheadBBC News23 May 201016 July 2010

article.heading: Fleet
Overview
article.paragraph: File:A380 & Red Arrows - RIAT 2013.jpgthumbG-XLEA, British Airways' first Airbus A380, accompanied by theRed Arrowsat 2013Royal International Air TattooWith the exception of theBoeing 707and earlyBoeing 747variants from BOAC, British Airways inherited a mainly UK-built fleet of aircraft when it was formed in 1974. The airline introduced theBoeing 737andBoeing 757into the fleet in the 1980s, followed by the Boeing 747-400,Boeing 767andBoeing 777in the 1990s. BA is now the largest operator of Boeing 747-400s, with 57 in its fleet.Prior to the introduction of the 787, when Boeing built an aircraft for British Airways, it was allocated theList of Boeing customer codescustomer code36, which appeared in their aircraft designation as a suffix, such as 737436.cite webhttp://www.caa.co.uk/application.aspx?catidCAA Aircraft Register (Boeing aircraft registered to British Airways)Civil Aviation Authority5 September 2009

In 1991, British Airways placed its first order for 777-200 aircraft, ordering another four for fleet expansion in 2007 at a cost of around US$800 million.Cite newshttp://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-30158167_ITMBoeing and British Airways complete deal for four 777-200ERs; Boeing 777 is logical complement to British Airways' wide-body fleetM2 Presswire28 March 200728 June 2010BA's first 777s were fitted withGeneral Electric GE90engines, but BA switched toRolls-Royce Trent 800sfor subsequent aircraft.cite webhttp://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-60879579.htmlRolls-Royce lands US jets dealBirmingham Evening Mail18 August 1998Cite newshttp://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-06/rolls-royce-wins-british-airways-order-for-trent-plane-engines.htmlBritish Airways Picks Troubled Rolls Engine for A380sHoward Mustoe, Steve RothwellBloomberg15 July 2013A BA Boeing 777-200 became the fastestsubsonic flightsubsonicNew York to London flight at 5 hours and 16 minutes in January 2015 due to strong winds.Cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/11337617/Jet-stream-blasts-BA-plane-across-Atlantic-in-record-time.htmlJet stream blasts BA plane across Atlantic in record timeCrillyBob[[The Daily Telegraph]]10 January 201513 January 2015London

Later in 2007, BA announced their order of thirty-six new long-haul aircraft, including twelveAirbus A380sand twenty-fourBoeing 787 Dreamliners.Cite newsBA opts for A380 and Dreamliner27 September 2007BBC Newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7015621.stm27 September 2007Rolls-Royce Trentengines were again selected for both orders with Trent 900s powering the A380s and Trent 1000s powering the 787s. The Boeing 787s will replace 14 of British Airways' Boeing 767 fleet, while the Airbus A380s will replace 20 of BA's Boeing 747-400s and will most likely be used to increase capacity on key routes from London Heathrow.

On 1 August 2008, BA announced orders for six Boeing 777-300ERs and options for four more as an interim measure to cover for delays over the deliveries of their 787-8/9s. Of the six that have been ordered, four will be leased and two will be fully acquired by British Airways.Cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?viewBA warns that ticket prices will jump as routes are axedDunkleyJamieThe Daily Telegraph1 August 20081 August 2008London

On 22 April 2013, IAG confirmed that it had signed a memorandum of understanding to order 18 A350-1000 aircraft for British Airways, with an option for a further 18. The aircraft would replace some of the airline's fleet of Boeing 747-400s.cite webhttp://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/iag-to-order-18-a350s-for-ba-384980/IAG to order 18 A350s for BAFlightglobal.com2013-04-222014-07-29Options for 18 Boeing 787 aircraft, part of the original contract signed in 2007, have been converted into firm orders for delivery between 2017 and 2021.CitationAirbus A350 for British AirwaysAirliner Worldp5June 2013

On 26 June 2013, British Airways took delivery of its first 787s. The aircraft began operations to Toronto on 1 September 2013, and began service to Newark on 1 October 2013.cite newshttp://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2013/09/02/ba_dreamliner_completes_inaugural_londontoronto_flight.htmlBA Dreamliner completes inaugural London-Toronto flightEllisonMarcToronto Star2 September 201313 September 2013BA's first A380 was delivered on 4 July 2013.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-23177384BA's first A380 superjumbo arrives at Heathrow airportBBC News4 July 2013It began regular services to Los Angeles on 24 September 2013, followed by Hong Kong on 22 October 2013.cite webWallRoberthttp://www.bloomberg.com/news/2013-03-05/british-airways-to-operate-first-a380s-to-los-angeles-hong-kong.htmlBritish Airways to Fly First A380s to Los Angeles, Hong KongBloomberg5 March 2013
The combined International Airlines Group entity (that BA is now a part of), operates around 400 aircraft, carries over 62 million passengers annually, and serves more than 200 destinations.

article.paragraph: The musical theme predominantly used on British Airways advertising is"The Flower Duet"byLo Delibes.cite webhttp://www.chrisworthproductions.com/track_details.php?idFlower Duet (From Lakme) by Leo DelibesChris Worth Productions8 June 2007This, and the slogan "The World's Favourite Airline" were introduced in 1989 with the launch of the iconicBritish Airways face advertisement"Face" advertisement.cite web//www.youtube.com/watch?v1989 British Airways CommercialYouTube19 January 2008The slogan was dropped in 2001 after Lufthansa overtook BA in terms of passenger numbers.Cite newsBritish Airways takes off22 May 2001http://money.cnn.com/2001/05/22/europe/ba/CNN28 June 2010"Flower Duet" is still used by the airline, and has been through several different arrangements since 1989. To Serve".cite newshttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2039678/British-Airways-relaunches-new-slogan-nods-imperial-origins.htmlBritish Airways relaunches itself with new slogan that nods to its imperial originsRay MasseyDaily Mail21 September 20116 July 2013

article.heading: Liveries and tail fins
article.paragraph: further2[[British Airways ethnic liveries]]File:Animalstrees.jpgthumbA British Airways Boeing 747-400 with a Utopia finFile:British Airways, Boeing 777-200ER, G-YMMH - LHR.jpgthumbA BA Boeing 777-200 with a Panda face, marking the launch of a route from London toChengduin 2013Since its formation in 1974, British Airways' aeroplanes carried aUnion Jackscheme painted on their tail fins. The original tail scheme was changed in 1984 as part of a new livery designed byLandor Associates.cite webRayMoseleyhttp://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/474804971.html?FMTBritish Airways scores big profit turnaraoundChicago Tribune12 January 1986

In 1997, there was a controversial change from the use of the former British Airways branding (which incorporated stylised elements of theUnion Jack) to a new livery which was intended mainly to reflect the diversity of places served by the airline so-called "World Images". This involved a range of different designs appearing on tailfins and elsewhere, although the bodies of all the planes would use the corporate colours consistently; the exception was the Concorde fleet, which would have a new tailfin design based on a stylised, fluttering Union flag.Cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/by-their-tailfins-shall-we-know-them-1256015.htmlBy their tailfins shall we know them?The Independent15 June 1997HughAldersey-Williams28 June 2010LondonWhat became known as the "ethnic images" included Delftware or Chinese calligraphy, related to countries on the company's network of routes. This was reported to have caused problems withair traffic control: previously controllers had been able to tell pilots to follow a BA plane, but they were now harder to visually identify.Cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/people--business-1155362.htmlPeople & BusinessThe Independent9 April 1998JohnWillcock28 June 2010LondonSeveral people spoke out against the change, including the former Prime MinisterMargaret Thatcher, who famously covered the tail of a model 747 at an event with a handkerchief, to show her displeasure.Cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/1324788.stmBA turns tail on coloursBBC News11 May 20016 July 2013BA's traditional rival, Virgin Atlantic, took advantage of the negative press coverage by applying the Union flag to the winglets of their aircraft along with the slogan "Britain's national flagcarrier".cite webhttp://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-60450784.htmlTony Parsons' column: Don't Jack it in yetThe Mirror14 June 1999ParsonsTony28 June 2010In 1999 the CEO of British Airways, Bob Ayling, announced that all BA planes would adopt the tailfin design originally intended to be used only on the Concorde, based on the Union Flag.Cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/news/union-jack-is-back-on-the-worlds-favourite-airline-1098648.htmlUnion Jack is back on the world's favourite airlineThe Independent7 June 199928 June 2010LondonWarwickMansell

article.paragraph: British Airways' tiered loyalty programme, called the Executive Club, includes access to special lounges and dedicated "fast" queues.Cite newshttp://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/money/consumer_affairs/article711216.eceNow you can fly further with air loyalty plansThe Times13 June 2009JessicaBown30 April 2006LondonBA also invites its top corporate accounts to join a "Premier" incentive programme. British Airways operates airside lounges for passengers travelling in premium cabins, and these are available to certain tiers of Executive Club members.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/lounges/public/en_gbLoungesBritish Airways17 September 2009First class passengers, as well as Gold Executive Club members, are entitled to use First Class Lounges. Business class passengers (called Club World or Club Europe in BA terms) as well as Silver Executive Club members may use Business lounges.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/first-lounges/public/en_gbFirst LoungesBritish Airways24 August 2010At airports in which BA does not operate a departure lounge, a third party lounge is often provided for premium or status passengers.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/ecbenftloungelist/public/en_gbLounge locationsBritish Airways17 September 2009In 2011, due to the merger with Iberia, British Airways announced changes to the Executive Club to maximise integration between the airlines.cite webRuthLythehttp://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2047270/The-great-Airmiles-rip--thousands-families-lose-trip-lifetime.html?itoThe great Airmiles rip-off... or how thousands of families will lose the trip of a lifetimeDaily Mail10 October 2011
article.heading: Inflight Magazines
article.paragraph: high life Magazineis the name for British Airways' complimentary inflight magazine. The magazine is available to all customers across all cabins and aircraft types.
high life shop Magazineis the name for British Airways' inflight shopping magazine. The magazine is available to all customers on all aircraft where the inflight shopping range can be carried.

First lifeis the name of the complimentary magazine offered to all customers travelling in the First cabin. The magazine has a of articles including fashion, trends and technology with an upmarket target audience.

Business lifeis the name of the complimentary magazine targeted towards the business traveller and frequent flyers of British Airways. The magazine can be found in all short haul aircraft seat pockets, in the magazine selection for Club World customers and in British Airways operated lounges.

article.heading: Short haul
Economy Class
article.paragraph: UK Domesticis British Airways'economy classon domestic UK flights. Flights into Heathrow are mostly operated by Airbus A320 series aircraft a small number of peak services to Glasgow and Edinburgh are operated by Boeing 767-300ERs configured in an all-economy layout. Flights into Gatwick are operated by Airbus A320 series aircraft in a one-class configuration. On flights departing before 09:30 a complimentary hot breakfast item is served with orange juice and tea or coffee. For all flights departing after 09:30 a complimentary bar service is offered along with a light snack item.

Euro Travelleris British Airways' economy class offering on flights from the UK to the rest of Europe.Heathrow based flights are operated by the Airbus A320 series aircraft and Boeing 767-300ER aircraft. Gatwick based flights are operated by Airbus A320 series aircraft. Standard seat pitch varies from 29" to 34" depending on aircraft type and location of seat. Complimentary drinks and snacks are offered and vary depending on flight length and time of day. Longer services over 3 hours from Heathrow usually have a hot meal service.
article.heading: Business Class
article.paragraph: Club Europeis the short-haul business class on all short-haul flights (excluding those within the UK). This class allows for access to business lounges at most airports.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/club-europe-lounges/public/en_gbClub Europe: LoungesBritish Airways5 September 2009cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/club-europe-dining/public/en_gbClub Europe: In-flight diningBritish Airways5 September 2009Club Europe provides seats in a 22 configuration on narrowbody aircraft, with the middle seat not used. Instead, a table folds up from under the middle seat on refurbished aircraft.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/ba6.jsp/wider-club-europe/public/en_gbWider seats in Club EuropeBritish Airways5 September 2009Pillows and blankets are available on longer flights.

In-flight entertainmentis offered on selected longer flights operated by the Boeing 767-300ER and some A320 aircraft.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/euro-traveller-seating/public/en_gbEuro Traveller: On-boardBritish Airways5 September 2009Headphones are provided to all customers on services where IFE is available.
article.heading: Mid-haul
article.paragraph: In 2012, British Airways launched a new mid-haul product for the Airbus A321s on routes formerly operated by BMI. These aircraft have been designated to serve routes such asAlmaty,Tbilisi,Baku,Cairo,Amman,BeirutandTel Aviv.
article.heading: Business
article.paragraph: TheClub Worldbusiness class on these narrowbody aircraft is slightly different from the product operated on the rest of the long-haul fleet: An alternating 1:2 / 2:1 configuration of 23 seats is used in the front section of the aircraft. The full Club World bar and main meal service is offered. Larger individual LCD TV screens are fitted to each seat back.
article.heading: Economy
article.paragraph: TheWorld Travellerservice is also offered on these flights with complimentary drinks, food and individual IFE screens. All seats on the aircraft are fitted with the Thales i5000 in-flight entertainment system.
article.heading: Long haul
First class
article.paragraph: First class (aviation)First classis offered on all Airbus A380s, most Boeing 747-400s, some Boeing 777-200s, and all Boeing 777-300ERs and Boeing 787-9s on launch. There are fourteen private "demi-cabins" on most of these aircraft, each with aconvert6ft6inmonbed, aconvert15incmonwide entertainment screen, and in-seat power.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/cms/global/microsites/ba_reports/business_review/br_future.htmlBritish Airways 2007/08 Annual Report and AccountsBritish Airways3 April 2009Cite newshttp://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/travel/news/article7007869.ece?tokenTimes report on BA First ClassThe TimesChrisHaslam31 January 20101 April 2010LondonDedicated British Airways 'Galleries First' lounges are available at some airports. The exclusive 'Concorde Room' lounges at Heathrow Terminal 5 and New York JFK airports extend the offering with waiter service pre-flight dining and more intimate space. Business lounges are used where these are not available.
article.heading: Business Class
article.paragraph: Club Worldis the long-haulbusiness class, and is offered on all long-haul configured Boeing 767, Boeing 777, Boeing 787, Boeing 747-400, Airbus A318 and A380 aircraft.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/cwonarrival/public/en_gbClub World: On arrivalBritish Airways5 September 2009cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/club-world-lounges/public/en_gbClub World: LoungesBritish Airways5 September 2009The cabin features fully flat beds. In 2006 British Airways launchedNext Generation New Club World, featuring larger seats.The Club World cabins are all configured in a similar design on widebody aircraft with aisle seats facing forwards while middle seats and window seats face backwards (British Airways is one of only three carriers with backwards facing Business class seats;American AirlinesandUnited Airlinesare the others.
article.heading: Premium Economy
article.paragraph: World Traveller Plusis thepremium economyoffering provided on all long-haul aircraft except the Airbus A318.cite webhttp://www.airlinequality.com/Product/seats_europe.htmBritish Airways seat-pitch guideSkytrax5 June 2010This cabin offers wider seats, extended leg-room, additional seat comforts such as larger IFE screen (on most aircraft) a foot rest and power sockets.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/world-traveller-plus-seating/public/en_gbWorld Traveller Plus InformationBritish Airways5 June 2010A complimentary 'World Traveller' bar is offered along with an upgraded main meal course.
article.heading: Economy
article.paragraph: World Travelleris the long-haul economy class offered on international flights to destinations outside Europe. It offers seat-back entertainment, complimentary drinks and meals.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/world-traveller-seating/public/en_gbWorld Traveller InformationBritish Airways5 June 2010cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/new-world-traveller/public/en_gbWorld Traveller – Preview our new CabinBritish Airways31 August 2010AVOD is offered on all A380s, 747s, long-haul 767s, and all of the 777s and 787s.cite webhttp://www.britishairways.com/travel/wt-entertainment/public/en_gbWorld Traveller EntertainmentOn the Airbus A380, Boeing 787, Boeing 777-300ER and refurbished 777-200 aircraft, AC power outlets and USB plug-in points are offered in every seat row. The outlets accept both UK and US plugs. The outlets in World Traveller are located between each seat.
article.heading: Incidents and accidents

list.listitem: In November 1974, British Airways Flight 870 was hijacked shortly after take-off fromDubaifor London Heathrow, TheVickers VC10landed atTripolifor refuelling before flying on to Tunis. The captain, Jim Futcher, returned to the aircraft to fly it knowing the hijackers were on board. The hijackers eventually surrendered after 84 hours, but not before a hostage was murdered. Futcher was awarded theQueen's Gallantry Medal, theGuild of Air Pilots and Air NavigatorsFounders Medal, theBritish Air Line Pilots AssociationGold Medal and a Certificate of Commendation from British Airways for his actions during the hijacking.Cite newshttp://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html? First Officer Mike Wood was awarded the same .resFour Hijackers Surrender; Tunisian Aide Denies Deal; Passengers in LondonThe New York Times26 November 197428 June 2010Cite newshttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/2055787/Captain-Jim-Futcher.htmlCaptain Jim FutcherThe Telegraph31 May 200831 May 2008London

On 10 September 1976, aHawker Siddeley TridentTrident 3Bon1976 Zagreb mid-air collisionBritish Airways Flight 476departed from London Heathrow to Istanbul. It collided in mid-air with anInex AdriaMcDonnell-Douglas DC-9DC9-31nearZagreb.cite webhttp://news.google.com/newspapers?idWorst midair crash ever claims 176 in YugoslaviaMilwaukee Sentinel11 September 197628 June 2010All 54 passengers and 9 crew members on the BA aircraft died. This is the only fatal accident to a British Airways aircraft since the company's formation in 1974.

On 24 June 1982,British Airways Flight 9, a Boeing 747-200 registrationG-BDXH, flew through a cloud of volcanic ash and dust from the eruption ofGalunggungMount Galunggung. The ash and dust caused extensive damage to the aircraft, including the failure of all four engines.Cite newshttp://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/683277272.html?didsJet Safe After Heart-Stopping, Dead-Engine DiveLos Angeles Times25 June 198228 June 2010The crew managed to glide the plane out of the dust cloud and restart all four of its engines, although one later had to be shut down again. The volcanic ash caused the cockpit window to be scratched to such an extent that it was difficult for the pilots to see out of the plane. However, the aircraft made a successful emergency landing atHalim Perdanakusuma International Airportjust outsideJakarta. There were no fatalities or injuries.Cite bookFaithNicholasBlack BoxBoxtree199619980-7522-2118-3156

On 10 June 1990,British Airways Flight 5390, aBAC One-Elevenflight betweenBirminghamandMlaga, suffered a windscreen blowout due to the fitting of incorrect bolts the previous day. The Captain, Tim Lancaster, suffered major injuries after being partially blown out of the aircraft, but the co-pilot landed the plane safely atSouthampton Airport. Despite the physical trauma he suffered, Lancaster fully recovered, and five months later he returned to duty. On 29 December 2000,British Airways Flight 2069was en route from London to Nairobi when a mentally-ill passenger entered the cockpit and grabbed the controls. As the pilots struggled to remove the intruder, theBoeing 747-400stalled twice and banked to 94 degrees. Several people on board were injured by the violent manoeuvres, which briefly caused the aircraft to descend at 30,000 ft per minute. The man was finally restrained with the help of several passengers, and the co-pilot regained control of the aircraft. The flight landed safely in Nairobi.

On 17 January 2008,British Airways Flight 38, aBoeing 777Boeing 777-200ERG-YMMM, departed fromBeijing Capital International AirportBeijingto London. It crash-landed approximatelyconvert1000ftmshort of London Heathrow Airport's runway 27L, and slid onto the runway'sdisplaced threshold. The aircraft sustained damage to its landing gear, wing roots and engines, resulting in the first hull loss of a Boeing 777. There were no fatalities, but there was one serious injury and 12 minor injuries. The accident was caused by icing in the fuel system, resulting in a loss of power.
